I say chicken, because the egg would have no source of warmth and therefore die. Whats your opinion?

post_info.post_title: What came first, the chicken or the egg?

I say chicken, because the egg would have no source of warmth and therefore die. Whats your opinion?

 I don't think you quite have the problem right.
 
 The point, at least from what I understand, is whether the chicken or the chicken egg came first. Did the first chicken come from a chicken egg or did it come from an egg that was not quite a chicken egg? Or was the first chicken egg laid by a chicken or a nearly-chicken?
 
 It is also easy to say that the egg came first if you count other eggs.
 
 Personally I would say the egg came first.
 
 Smiley

 It is also easy to say that the egg came first if you count other eggs.
 
 Personally I would say the egg came first.

 Personally, I don't think it was intended as an evolution thing. Then again, I don't think it was intended to have scientific improbabilities pointed out either.

Personally, I don't think it was intended as an evolution thing. Then again, I don't think it was intended to have scientific improbabilities pointed out either.

 Fair enough!

A genetic change would have to take place in one cell - either the zygote or earlier in the egg/sperm. Otherwise, the changed gene wouldn't be able to spread out to the whole organism.
 
 So going by the lowest number: 
 -egg/sperm cell
 -zygote or the early stages after
 -sexual organ that produces the egg/sperm

I say chicken, because the egg would have no source of warmth and therefore die. Whats your opinion?

 True, but wouldn't that chicken have been a baby at some point? And wouldn't that baby chicken have been hatched from an egg as well?

True, but wouldn't that chicken have been a baby at some point? And wouldn't that baby chicken have been hatched from an egg as well?

 
 If there was no chicken around to nurse the egg, the chicken couldn't have come from an egg.

If there was no chicken around to nurse the egg, the chicken couldn't have come from an egg.

 The mother/nursing chicken certainly helps provide the conditions for the survival of the egg, but its not impossible for that egg to have those perfect conditions in the absense of a mother.

The mother/nursing chicken certainly helps provide the conditions for the survival of the egg, but its not impossible for that egg to have those perfect conditions in the absense of a mother.

 
 Where on earth could an egg be in the right conditions to hatch?

Where on earth could an egg be in the right conditions to hatch?

 All an egg needs in order to hatch is 99.5 degrees F for 21 days. How hard could that be?

All an egg needs in order to hatch is 99.5 degrees F for 21 days. How hard could that be?

 
 What about night? I just think it would be extremely hard to find a place that is 99.5 degrees for 21 days.

Work it out.....
 
 
 A chicken and an egg are lying in bed. The chicken is smoking a cigarette with a satisfied smile on its face and the egg is frowning and looking a bit browned off. The egg mutters, to no-one in particular, "Well, I guess we answered THAT question!"

What about night? I just think it would be extremely hard to find a place that is 99.5 degrees for 21 days.

 Not that hard. Geothermal activity, rotting vegetation, chemical reactions, etc, all provide consistent sources of warmth independent of the sun. For example, an egg at just the right distance from a magma vent in a cave could provide identical conditions to a modern incubator. Also, a mammal or bird other than a chicken, example safely nestling the egg under the armpit of a hibernating bear, could hatch the egg just as a mother chicken would.

Crocodilians lay their eggs in a "nest" of vegetation which maintains a constant temperature....
 
 " An alligator nest is a pile of rotting grass, other vegetation and mud. The pile is 3 1/2 to 6 feet across and 1 to 2 feet high, sitting in a site 13 to 18 feet across that has been cleared of vegetation by the female. By the first week in July, she lays a clutch of 20 to 70 cylindrical eggs. The eggs are 3 to 3 1/2 inches long, about 1 1/2 inches in diameter, and are buried 3 to 14 inches deep in the nests. Incubation takes about 65 days. 
 
 The female alligator stays close to guard the eggs from raiding raccoons, skunks and opossums. ..... "
 
 
 http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/huntwild/wild/species/alligator/nest/index.phtml

A little boy and a little girl attended the same school and became friends.
 Every day they would sit together to eat their lunch. They discovered that they both brought chicken sandwiches every day! This went on all through the fourth and fifth grades, until one day he noticed that her sandwich wasn't a chicken sandwich. 
 
 He said, 'Hey, how come you're not eating chicken, don't you like it anymore?'
 
 She said 'I love it but I have to stop eating it.' 
 
 'Why?' he asked.
 
 She pointed to her lap and said 'Cause I'm starting to grow little feathers down there!'
 
 'Let me see' he said.
 
 'Okay' and she pulled up her skirt. 
 
 He looked and said, 'That's right. You are! Better not eat any more chicken.' 
 
 He kept eating his chicken sandwiches until one day he brought peanut butter.
 
 He said to the little girl, 'I have to stop eating chicken sandwiches, I'm starting to get feathers down there too!' 
 
 She asked if she could look, so he pulled down his pants for her! 
 
 She said 'Oh, my God, it's too late for you! You've already got the NECK and GIZZARDS!!!
